Award.AwardTitle: US-URUGUAY-BRAZIL Collaborative IRES: Ampullariidae Model using Phylogeography, Laboratory Integration with Field Investigations into Ecology and Diversity (AMPLIFIED)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative International Research Experience for Students (IRES) award will support 15 U.S. undergraduate students and one graduate student, under the direction of Drs. Romi Burks from Southwestern University and Kenneth Hayes from University of Hawaii, to carry out collaborative research in Brazil and Uruguay for three years. The program is co-organized by Dr. Silvano Thiengo from the Instituto Oswaldo Cruz in Brazil and Dr. Mariana Meerhoff from the Universidad de la Republica in Uruguay. The goal of the project is to create an Ampullariidae model for a group of aquatic snails commonly called apple snails using phylogeography, laboratory integration, and field inquiry. Brazil harbors the greatest number of ampullariid species and genera and provides the largest latitudinal span (~37º) of any country in South America. Additionally, the original Guaraní, word "Uruguay" translated into Spanish as "river of the snails." Study of the phylogeny of these snails can be used to investigate important evolutionary processes, particularly those associated with major habitat transitions (e.g. marine to freshwater to terrestrial). Students' research will focus on quantifying genetic variation in this understudied group of aquatic snails, identifying patterns of speciation, investigating traits that promote invasiveness, and determining reproductive potential.
This IRES award brings together a diverse community of researchers and students from the United States, Brazil, and Uruguay. In addition to working directly with the host scientists, U.S. students will blog about their international research experience and work closely with other undergraduate and graduate students from the host country. Participating students will also develop educational materials that can be used locally in their host countries. Upon return to their home institution, students will disseminate their results through professional meetings, scientific publications, and social media networks. The research also has important societal benefits as apple snails are highly invasive species and vectors of parasitic nematodes that can cause illness in mammals, including humans. Insights into how the trophic roles that these snails inhabit in native habitats may lend insight into how to deal with their presence in invaded wetland ecosystems such as the Florida Everglades.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Apple snails are a group of freshwater snails scientifically known as members of the family Ampullariidae. These snails are found in a variety of slow-flowing bodies of water, including shallow lakes, ponds, drainage ditches and flood plains, in the humid tropics and subtropics. The majority of species occur in South America and in their native ranges, apple snails are considered major components of aquatic ecosystems and essential for proper ecosystem function. In recent years, they have gained significant attention because a few species have been introduced outside of their native range and become major agricultural pests of rice and other aquatic crops. One species in particular, Pomacea canaliculata, is considered the number one pest of rice in the world and known to be a carrier of parasites that cause human diseases. Because of their importance in proper functioning of ecosystems and the major impacts they have in agricultural and natural aquatic systems in their non-native habitats, apple snails offer excellent opportunities and a tractable system to address fundamental questions regarding basic biology, ecology and evolution.

The IRES-AMPLIFIED (Ampullariidae Model using Phylogeography, Laboratory Integration and Field Investigations into Ecology and Diversity) project aimed to take advantage of this system to provide an exciting and tractable research program that provide opportunities to students to gain experience conducting international and national research in Uruguay, Brazil and the United States of America. The project involved close collaborations between two Research I institutions (The University of Hawaii and Howard University) and a small liberal arts college - Southwestern University along with a host of additional academic, and non-academic partners. This diverse group of freshwater snails and the host of questions they provide regarding physiology, ecology, evolution, behavior, invasion biology and disease transmission provided dynamic independently-driven research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students combined with international research experiences.

Our broad research approaches integrated studies of species diversity and the processes that shape it through a combination of field surveys, anatomical examination, genetic analysis, experimental manipulation and museum research on a several species occurring across Uruguay, Argentina and Brazil. Brazil harbors the greatest number of ampullariid species and genera and provides the largest latitudinal span (~37º) of any country in South America, thereby facilitating diverse comparative studies within and among species and genera. The original Guaraní, word “Uruguay” translated into Spanish as “river of the snails” and Uruguay represents an often overlooked opportunity for international scientific collaboration among South American countries. Thus, these countries provided ideal research sites for international work on apple snails.

In addition to the basic research, with its broader impacts related to invasive species problems and to apple snail biology generally, the project permitted extensive outreach, disseminating the results not only to the scientific community but more broadly, and notably in generating datasheets for invasive species for various national and international agencies. Project personnel frequently responded to requests for expert advice from environmental and agricultural managers, aquaculturists, officials dealing with invasive species, and the general public.

Research projects developed within the AMPLIFIED framework spanned a number of areas from quantifying genetic variation in this understudied group of aquatic snails, examining the role of mating behaviors and possible hybridization between species, to investigating interactions between native and non-native species and determining the functional role of these snails in aquatic systems.  Study of these snails can be used to investigate important evolutionary processes, particularly those associated with major habitat transitions (e.g. marine to freshwater to terrestrial). In terms of applied work, this project, particularly the focus and expertise of Principal Investigator Dr. Kenneth A. Hayes, has served to increase the clarity regarding the identity and classification of apple snails species, and provided insights into the processes that drive diversification within the family.

Over the span of the project, 18 students participated directly in research projects developed as part of the award, the majority from groups often underrepresented in science fields. Of these, 16 students (4 graduate students, 12 undergraduates) traveled to South America (3 to Brazil; 13 to Uruguay) to conduct research on apple snails with host scientists. The project also facilitated the development of new collaborations between researchers in the US and China, where apple snails are a major problem for agriculture and disease. The work developed as part of this collaboration will provide rich opportunities for future students working with Hayes on apple snails.
